title: Former NAB financial adviser sentenced
text:
Former National Australia Bank financial adviser Max Eung has been sentenced to a three-year intensive correction order by the New South Wales District Court for taking $166,000 from his clients.

Eung was convicted and sentenced on Friday after pleading guilty to dishonestly obtaining financial advantage and of creating false bank accounts in the names of his clients.

The crimes were committed in 2016 and the case followed a referral by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission,

Eung was banned from providing financial advice in the middle of last year, a decision which was welcomed by NAB general manager of financial planning Tim Steele.

"We sacked Mr Eung on 20 December 2016 after a routine security process identified serious compliance concerns. We reported the events to the NSW police, notified ASIC and have fully cooperated with their investigation," Mr Steele said at the time.

ASIC Commissioner Sean Hughes said Eung breached his clients' trust by using their confidential information to create false accounts as well as by accessing his clients’ funds to use for his own benefit,
description: Max Eung will serve a three-year intensive correction order after pleading guilty to taking $166,000 from clients
